title: Australia's deadliest jobs revealed
text:
Just six industries were home to 80 per cent of deaths﻿ in the workplace last year.

Safe Work Australia has released its new Key Work Health and Safety Statistics Australia report, which revealed 188 people were fatally injured ﻿at work in 2024 - a decline on 200 in 2023.

The watchdog said 80 per cent of these deaths had taken place across just six industries - agriculture, forestry, and fishing; public administration and safety; transport, postal, and warehousing; manufacturing; health care and social assistance; and construction.

Workplace safety continued to improve across Australia last year. (Getty)

The report also showed vehicle incidents remained the leading cause of job deaths (42 per cent, or 79 fatalities), followed by falls from a height (13 per cent, or 24 fatalities).

And while Australia's workplace safety generally compares well to the rest of the world, with an injury rate of 3.5 per cent compared to the global 12.1 per cent, Safe Work Australia says the impact is still deeply felt.

In 2023–24, there were 146,700 serious workers' compensation claims involving at least one week of working time lost, equivalent to more than 400 serious claims every day.

READ MORE: Woman randomly stabbed while walking to work in broad daylight

Claims for mental health conditions continue to rise and now account for 12 per cent of all serious claims, an increase of 14.7 per cent from the previous year.

The median time lost from work in these claims is almost five times that recorded across all other injuries and diseases.

"Our data show there is still more to be done to ensure every worker, regardless of occupation or industry, returns home safely at the end of the day," Safe Work Australia chief executive Marie Boland said.

"Behind every statistic is a person, a family, workmates, a community and a story."

title: Over 13,000 Nissan cars recalled over fuel pipe issue
text:
A range of Nissan cars have been recalled over fears they could result in a 'loss of motive power' and potentially even start a vehicle fire.

In the official notice online, Vehicle Recalls﻿ said that due to a manufacturing defect in the affected cars, the fuel pipe might chafe against the support bracket and suffer damage.

"If this occurs fuel may leak, potentially resulting in loss of motive power whilst driving, and if in the presence of an external ignition source may result in a vehicle fire," the notice read.

A range of Nissan cars have been pulled off the roads due to safety fears. (Supplied)

It could increase the risk﻿ of injury and even death to people within or outside the car.

"Owners of affected vehicles will be contacted in writing requesting they contact an authorised Nissan dealer to have their vehicle rectified, free of charge," the notice said.

﻿The affected cars include ICE variants of the J12 Qashqai model, made in 2022 to 2024.

About 13,000 cars are affected. (Supplied)

There are 13,031 cars affected.

For more information, contact Nissan Austrapo1800 035 035 or online .﻿

title: Cancelling a gym membership? These are your consumer rights in Australia
text:
There's nothing worse than deciding to cancel a gym membership only to be slapped with hefty termination fees.﻿

The average Australian with a gym membership spends $756 per year on working out according to Canstar, which is equivalent to about $63 per month﻿.

Here's ﻿what you need to know about your consumer rights when cancelling a gym membership.

The average Australian with a gym membership spends $63 per month﻿, which adds up in a cost of living crisis. (Getty)

Do you have the right to cancel a gym membership?

Yes, you have the right to cancel gym memberships.

However the terms of your cancellation may vary depending on the gym.

Some gyms enforce specific rules around cancellation, such as charging a fee or requiring members to attend the gym in-person to cancel.

"Businesses should provide clear and accurate information to consumers up-front about the memberships or subscriptions they are offering," a spokesperson for the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) told 9news.com.au.

"Including any automatic renewal of the contract, consumers' ability to cancel the contract, and any cancellation fees that might apply and when﻿."

What are the rules around cancelling a gym membership?﻿

This depends on the specific gym you're signed up with and what contract you're on.

﻿The first step for anyone looking to cancel their gym membership is to check the cancellation terms on their contract.

If you only recently joined the gym, you may be able to quit without paying a fee if you're still in a cooling-off period﻿.

These are in place to ensure members who cancel within a set time (typically within seven days of joining) only pay for administration costs or services used, not the full contracted membership period.

Other common terms include a mandatory notice period, or termination fees.

"Some states and territories also have additional protections for consumers in state-specific laws regarding gym memberships," the ACCC spokesperson said.

"For example, in Queensland, the Fitness Industry Code of Practice contains requirements that gyms must meet regarding disclosure of information in membership agreements, cooling off periods, the notice period a gym must give before renewing an agreement, and termination of membership agreements."

READ MORE: How to maximise public holidays and make the most of your annual leave in 2025

There are some things that can't be included in gym ﻿contracts under the Australian Consumer Law. (Getty)

What can't a gym do ﻿when a member cancels?

Most gym memberships are based on a standard form contract﻿ and there are certain things that can't be included in these under the Australian Consumer Law.

"Businesses can include requirements for, and conditions on, cancellations in their contracts," an ACCC spokesperson said.

"However, they need to take care to ensure such terms are not unfair contract terms."

Unfair contract terms include:

terms that would cause a significant imbalance in the parties' rights and obligations under the contract

terms that are not reasonably necessary to protect the business

terms that would cause detriment (financial or otherwise) to a consumer

Gyms caught proposing, using, or relying on unfair contract terms in standard form contracts can face fines up to $2.5 million for individuals and $50 million for businesses.

"If consumers have a dispute about a gym membership or subscription, they should contact their local state or territory consumer protection agency in the first instance," the ACCC spokesperson said.

"They can also report the issue to the ACCC.

How to cancel a gym membership﻿

Once you're across the terms of your contract, you can request to cancel your gym membership – this can usually be done in-person, over the phone or online.

Regardless of how you cancel, always get confirmation of your cancellation in writing with proof of the date you cancelled.

This is because many gyms require members to give notice of cancellation in advance to stop payments.

How much notice do you have to give to cancel a gym membership?

Aussies must give gyms up to 30 days ﻿notice when cancelling a membership, during which time they will still be charged for the service.

Notice periods vary from gym to gym, but cannot be more than 30 days.

This is sometimes known as ﻿a four-week cancellation policy.

Can gyms charge you to cancel membership?

Yes, gyms can charge termination fees when you cancel a membership.

﻿These must be laid out clearly in your contract under the Australian Consumer Law.

Cancelling gym memberships online

Some gyms require members to attend the gym in-person to cancel a membership.

Check your contract to see if this applies at your gym.﻿

title: Are we in an AI tech bubble and what happens if it bursts?
text:
According to the valuations, the company behind ChatGPT is now worth more than what the entire state of Victoria produces in a year, and it's not far off NSW.

Artificial intelligence, its builders say, has almost unlimited potential to radically transform – or maybe even destroy – the world.

But more and more finance, business and tech experts watching the staggering firehose of money pouring into the sector are starting to question whether the multitrillion-dollar industry is one big bubble. And what happens if it bursts?

If you believe the valuations, the company behind ChatGPT is now worth more than what the entire state of Victoria produces in a year, and it's not far off NSW. (AP)

The Bank of England warned of an increasing risk of "a sharp market correction", Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon said "a lot of capital" wouldn't deliver returns and the International Monetary Fund's chief economist, Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas, said after surging valuations and booming investments, "markets could reprice sharply".

Using simpler words, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos called it "kind of an industrial bubble".

Even Sam Altman, the head of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, asked directly if investors were "overexcited about AI", flat out said "yes".

"When bubbles happen, smart people get overexcited about a kernel of truth," he told reporters at The Verge and some other tech publications in August.

"If you look at most of the bubbles in history, like the tech bubble, there was a real thing. Tech was really important. The internet was a really big deal. People got overexcited."

Even Sam Altman, the head of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, asked directly if investors were "overexcited about AI", flat out said "yes". (AP)

What even is a bubble?

So, are they right? And what happens if the AI bubble bursts?

Stanford Graduate School of Business Professor Anat Admati says the concept of a bubble is not well defined, and it's almost impossible to identify one in real time.

"Stock valuation and timing stocks is very difficult because the stock reflects the entire future and all lots and lots of factors," she tells 9news.com.au.

"So the notion that you're diagnosing a bubble as it's happening is often folly.

"People form beliefs and decide to trade, and it's a very dangerous game to play for investors, for pundits, journalists like yourself."

The OpenAI logo is seen on a mobile phone in front of a computer screen displaying output from ChatGPT. (AP)

Oxford Economics lead economist Adam Slater sees "some symptoms of a bubble", including rapid growth in tech stock prices and the fact tech stocks now comprise about 40 per cent of the S&P 500 stock market tracking the 500 leading US companies.

He also points to market valuations that appear "stretched" beyond their worth and "a general sense of extreme optimism in terms of the underlying technology, despite the enormous uncertainties around what this technology might ultimately yield".

Some analysts suggest AI could lead to productivity gains not seen since Europe after World War II, while Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist Daron Acemoglu has predicted a 0.7 per cent gain in US productivity over a decade.

"You've got this incredibly wide range of possibilities," Slater says.

"Nobody really knows where it's going to land."

OpenAI isn't the only player in the AI game. (Getty)

Is this the dotcom boom 2.0?

The easy comparison, which even Altman and his Open AI chairman, Bret Taylor, have made, is with the dotcom boom, when the tech-heavy NASDAQ surged almost 600 per cent in the mid-to-late '90s before wiping off almost all of those games in about a year and a half.

A swathe of start-ups were wiped out and even big hitters still around today such as Microsoft, Oracle and Intel took a battering on the markets.

Admati says it's too hard to predict whether a potential AI bubble bursting would do anything more than correcting the price of some companies, much less when it might happen.

A swathe of start-ups were wiped out and even big hitters still around today such as Microsoft, Oracle and Intel took a battering on the markets. (AP)

"The internet bubble burst didn't change the entire world economy," she says.

"It was a price correction in a relatively narrow sector."

Taylor puts a positive on the comparison, saying you could argue people pouring money into internet stocks in 1999 were broadly right.

"If you look at the internet bubble, a lot of people think about the flops, like Pets.com and Webvan," he tells The Verge.

"Through the lens of the past 30 years, though, we've now gotten most of the largest companies in the world, including Amazon and Google, two of the largest companies in the world."

Taylor argues people pouring money into internet stocks in 1999 were broadly right. (AP Photo/Richard Drew FILE)

'It's the fear of missing out'

OpenAI is the most striking example of AI investment because it's come from nothing to be one of the world's most hyped companies in a few years based solely on the promise of its tech.

It is now valued at roughly $US500 billion ($771.9 billion), not too far below the GDP of Austria ($804.1 billion) or the 2023-24 GSP (gross state product) of NSW ($821 billion).

But the big boys are also shovelling money into their large language models and other AI research.

Google is all-in on AI across its phones and even search and just this week announced another $US15 billion investment in an AI data hub, Amazon looks set to spend $US100 billion ($154.5 billion) on the technology this year, Apple boss Tim Cook told employees the AI revolution was "as big or bigger" as the internet, smartphones, cloud computing and apps.

Google's Gemini AI assistant. (Google)

Chipmaker NVIDIA's surge to become the biggest company in the world by market capitalisation – overtaking even Apple – was so dramatic that it spurred a wave of articles about how the name is pronounced (en-VID-eeyah, by the way).

It was driven by a ravenous demand for the company's high-end GPUs, prized above all else in battle for the massive amounts of computing power it takes to sustain these huge companies' AI computing demands.

So when it invested $US100 billion in OpenAI, which, as well as being one of its main customers, has a 10 per cent stake in chip rival AMD, eyebrows were raised at this "circular" financing.

AMD and OpenAI have agreed to a multibillion-dollar deal. (AP)

"A small group of companies is securing most of the major deals. News about multibillion-dollar investments from familiar companies such as OpenAI, Nvidia, CoreWeave, Microsoft, Google, and a few others is reported almost daily," Yale School of Management leadership expert Professor Jeffrey A Sonnenfeld and senior research fellow Stephen Henriques wrote in an opinion piece called This is how the AI bubble bursts.

"Should the bold promises of AI fall short, the dependence among these major AI players could trigger a devastating chain reaction, causing a widespread collapse similar to the 2008 Great Financial Crisis."

Henriques tells 9news.com.au the risks are likely closer to those of the dotcom boom, where there is promise that "will take a lot longer to materialise than people expect".

"It's the fear of missing out," Sonnenfeld says.

"Everybody you know thinks that the costs of missing it are too high, enterprise wise and career wise, to look like you're an anachronism."

Microsoft is a major investor in OpenAI. (AP)

In their article, the researchers point out that in less than three years, OpenAI has "gone from a parlour game to a pillar of the global economy".

"After pillar, you wonder if you're going to wind up with a pile of rubble, and how to then rebuild out of the shakeout, where you see a lot of damage and carnage done," Sonnenfeld tells 9news.com.au.

The upside

Bezos argues the AI boom will be good for the world even if the bubble bursts, describing it as industrial, rather than financial or banking.

"The ones that are industrial are not nearly as bad. It could even be good because when the dust settles and you see who are the winners, society benefits from those inventions," Bezos said at a recent tech conference in Italy.

He compared it to a previous biotech bubble in the 1990s that resulted in new life-saving drugs.

"Every company gets funded, the good ideas and the bad ideas. And investors have a hard time in the middle of this excitement distinguishing between the good and bad ideas and so that's also probably happening today," he said.

Altman last month predicted people would "make some dumb capital allocations", resulting in short-term ups and downs.

But he was confident it would drive "a new wave of unprecedented economic growth", scientific breakthroughs, improvements to quality of life and "new ways to express creativity".

title: Rock legend dies aged 74
text:
Ace Frehley, the original lead guitarist and founding member of the glam rock band KISS who captivated audiences with his elaborate makeup and smoke-filled guitar, has died. He was 74.

The American rock star died peacefully on Thursday (Friday AEDT )surrounded by family in the north-eastern state of New Jersey following a recent fall, according to his agent.

Family members said in a statement that they are "completely devastated and heartbroken", but will cherish his laughter and celebrate the kindness he bestowed upon others.

Ace Frehley, left, of the rock band KISS has died aged 74. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello) (AP)

In this 2009 photo, former KISS lead guitarist Ace Frehley plays the national anthem before an NFL football game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the New York Giants in Kansas City, Mo. (AP Photo/L.G. Patterson, File) (AP)

Kiss, whose hits include Rock and Roll All Nite and Detroit Rock City , was known for its intense stage shows, which included fireworks, smoke and eruptions of fake blood performed by band members in black-and-white painted faces, platform boots and black wigs.

Frehley and his band mates were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2014.

title: Jamie wanted a job at Woolies. He claims he was rejected after two AI interviews
text:
Exclusive: A young Australian claims he was rejected from an entry-level job at Woolworths despite never speaking to a single human being in the hiring process.

﻿Jamie, 24, said he applied to work part-time at his local Woolworths in NSW and was subjected to two "odd" AI interviews, only to be rejected six weeks later.

He called the whole experience "dystopian", especially coming from "one of the most profitable companies in Australia﻿".

READ MORE: Hero tradie foils alleged attempted armed robbery

Jamie, 24, from NSW applied for a job at Woolies and said he was rejected after two AI interviews. (TikTok/@jammy_dunk/Getty)

Woolworths' profits in 2024-25 hit nearly $1.4 billion.﻿

"I find it really hard to believe the company that makes that much money every year couldn't afford to have a human interview me," Jamie told 9news.com.au.

But experts say this is what the future of job hunting looks like.

Jamie applied for a role at his local Woolworths in September and said the online application mentioned "AI may be involved" in the hiring process.

He didn't know what that meant at first.﻿

"Almost immediately, I got the invite to do the first AI interview," Jamie said.

He had to provide written answers to questions from a text-based AI chatbot within a time limit.

"It kind of made me wonder, who is actually looking over this after you've completed it?" he said, calling the interview "strange".

Australia named the most 'AI-addicted' country. See how others ranked View Gallery

A few days later, he got an email inviting him to another AI interview with a text-based chatbot.

This time he had to provide voice and video responses, which he wasn't entirely comfortable with.

"I'm not sure how I feel about this really massive company having access to my voice and video," he said.

Woolworths declined to comment, however 9news.com.au understands Woolworths uses AI as part of its hiring process for store roles.

Jamie said he didn't hear back from Woolworths until about six weeks later, when he received a generic rejection email with no human feedback.

"That was really like a little kick in the guts," he said.

He's just grateful he was able to support himself financially while waiting to hear back.﻿

"If you're nearly destitute, or you're really struggling, living paycheck to paycheck or on Centrelink, that six-week wait could kill you," he said.

He shared his frustrations in a TikTok video which has since been viewed about 100,000 times.

Jamie applied for a role at his local Woolworths in September and was invited to two AI interviews. (Getty)

Many Aussies like Jamie are resistant to the idea of AI job interviews but ﻿Associate Professor of workplace and business law at the University of Technology, Sydney Giuseppe Carabetta said we should probably get used to it.

"Larger organisations are using things like CV scanners, video interview analysis, and personality assessments or tests," he told 9news.

"This is generally about faster screening and processes – but there are problems, including the risk of biases where you have AI replicating historical discrimination by humans (algorithmic discrimination)."

﻿There is currently no legislation that directly regulates the use of AI in recruitment but anti-discrimination laws require employers to ensure that recruitment practices do not discriminate based on attributes like race, sex, and ability.

Those laws technically apply to AI systems, but they often "fall between the legal cracks" in recruitment.

For example, an employer could land in hot water if an ﻿AI recruitment system automatically rejects applicants with feminine-sounding names (gender discrimination).

But even that could be hard for an employee to prove or pursue legally, as anti-discrimination law normally applies to the actions of a physical person.

Anti-discrimination laws technically apply to AI systems but can be hard to enforce. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Carabetta said that AI use in recruitment is an area ripe for reform but ﻿"unfortunately the law is slow to adapt and legislative reform is not easy or quick".

And in the meantime, there's not much Aussies can do to avoid AI interviews.﻿

"There is no direct legal right for jobseekers to request a human interview instead of an AI one," he said.

Aussies with a disability can ﻿request "reasonable adjustments" under the Disability Discrimination laws, which could include asking for a human interviewer.

"But for other candidates – for example, those uncomfortable with AI – there is no formal right to opt out of AI interviews."

Jobseekers can try to take steps to secure ﻿a human interview, like asking early on if interviews will be conducted using AI and voicing a preference for human interaction.

READ MORE: Cause of crash under investigation as soldier remembered as leader and mentor

Want a pay rise? These jobs experienced the fastest salary growth this year View Gallery

They can also seek out ﻿employers that still emphasise 'traditional' recruitment methods, like handing in a physical resume, or reach out to hiring managers directly.

But there's no guarantee any of that will prevent jobseekers from having to deal with AI at some point in the hiring process.

Carabetta encouraged Aussie jobseekers to learn how AI is used in modern hiring and try to adapt to it – because it's "absolutely" not going away.﻿

title: 'Kidding me': Aussie's hopeful attempt to dodge post office visit backfires
text:
An Australia Post customer has been left scratching their head after missing an important parcel delivery - despite not only being home all day, but even putting up a sign to let the postie know.

The customer posted a photo earlier this week to Reddit showing them giving a thumbs-up after posting the sign on the mailbox.

"Auspost, I am home!" it read.

A Reddit poster was optimistic about getting their parcel delivered after putting up this helpful sign. (Reddit)

"I can help with my package if need be as it is heavy. Please feel free to knock and ask!"

The customer said similar missed drop-offs had happened before.

"Very expensive and large package coming today … ain't no way in hell I'm driving to the airport to pick it up because of my area's driver!" they wrote.

"He loves to just put in the 'we missed you' note and speed off, and that's if he even finds the motivation to leave a note at all!"

No such luck. (Reddit)

Despite their precautions, a predictable - if amusing - update soon followed.

"Are you f------ kidding me," they wrote, holding up a familiar red-and-white collection slip.

Oddly, despite the cu﻿stomer offering to help due to the package's weight, the "heavy" box was not checked on the card.

The customer's post sparked a long thread of replies, many of them featuring similar tales of woe.

The customer confirmed they were not following the matter up with Australia Post. (Getty)

In follow-up replies, the customer clarified their package had weighed about 9 to 10 kilograms, well within delivery limits.

They also said ﻿they had since taken possession of their package.

"Hell, I barely even lodged a minor complaint at the office and haven't even called up auspost (sic) to back it," they said.

"I don't plan on pursuing it because there's no point, it'd only create more negativity and I already have my package."

An Australia Post spokesperson said delivery drivers were subject to "strict protocols", which required them to knock three times and wait 30 seconds.﻿

"Drivers are also required to take a photo of the front door or intercom, and photos can be viewed through the Aus Post app," the spokesperson said.

"Customers with any concerns about their delivery are encouraged to contact Australia Post via our website ( auspost.com.au ) or calling 13 POST (13 76 78)."

text:

title: 'No doubt' Albanese and Trump will discuss critical minerals: Chalmers
text:
A critical minerals deal will "no doubt" be part of discussions between Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump next week, the treasurer has confirmed.

Speaking from Washington, where he is meeting American counterparts ahead of the prime minister's official visit next week, Jim Chalmers said Australia could be a "reliable partner" of the valuable commodities as the US seeks alternative buyers in a market dominated by China.

"We know that American companies desperately need critical minerals, and Australia is very well placed to service that need," he said.

"This will be an important part of the discussions that I have … and no doubt it will be part of the discussions that Prime Minister Albanese has with President Trump next week."

Jim Chalmers travelled to the United States for talks ahead of the prime minister's arrival. (ABC News: Callum Flinn)

The cluster of prized metals, which Australia has in abundance but does not yet sell at scale, have long been speculated as an enticing offering for a president who takes an unapologetically transactional approach to diplomacy.

Last week, trade minister Don Farrell said his US counterpart had raised the issue with him and that a deal would be struck "one of these days", suggesting it would involve some sort of US investment to help make Australian mining operations viable, in exchange for some form of guaranteed US access to what was extracted.

The issue has gained further prominence in recent weeks after Chinese threats to use its dominance to control the supply of the minerals, which are important for renewable technology and artificial intelligence.

The US also requires the minerals for most of its weapons.

Earlier this week, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent called China's move "an exercise in economic coercion on every country in the world" and a step towards "decoupling" between China and the west.

As China flexes dominance on rare earths, Australia sees an opening Trump may have expressed "shock", but his administration is clearly not surprised at China's willingness to flex its dominance on rare earths.

Mr Bessent vowed to speak with allies, including Australia, on "a fulsome group response".

"China cannot manage the supply chain or the manufacturing process for the rest of the world," he told US network CNBC.

Mr Chalmers said Australia's interests were "best served by more trade, not by more trade barriers".

"We will engage with our partners to make sure that we can be a very reliable supplier to meet the critical minerals needs of this country, here in the US and other markets around the world," he said.

He said Australia was concerned that the market for critical minerals was not as reliable and robust as it could be when it came to the supply chains.

"Australia's got a lot to offer to the world," he said.

Subsidising a new mining boom

To grow the domestic industry, the Australian government has been considering subsidising the production and sale of critical minerals operations to give would-be mining investors the confidence they would otherwise lack.

On the production side, it already offers a variety of tax credits and cash injections under the banner of its industry support regime Future Made in Australia, which has a particular emphasis on "green" applications for the metals.

On the sale side, it has pledged $1.2 billion for a "strategic reserve" of the minerals, slated for next year but still in its design phase.

US wants Australia's rare earths As rare earths re-emerge as a central battleground in the US-China trade war, Australian companies are already striking deals to supply America.

Though this may include a physical stockpile, it is more likely to be an assurance that miners will receive a minimum price for what they can produce.

Miners could then strike future purchase agreements with buyers, backed by the comfort that the government would make good on the minimum price if market conditions were unfavourable.

The government's involvement may take the form of a financial derivative, a "paper promise" to make up any price shortfall, but where the government would itself profit if the price was higher than expected.

While the idea of price security was that it would create the space for Australian miners to enter into voluntary and profitable deals with foreign buyers, the government intended to partner with its allies to guide that process along.

This is where the US could come in, perhaps agreeing to invest in mining operations in exchange for some sort of preferential access to what those operations produce. Similar discussions are already underway with Japan, South Korea, and Europe.

China's threats to exert greater control over not just the export and refinement of minerals, but also their applications, has catapulted the issue to front of mind for the US government, which has begun stockpiling minerals with defence applications.

While it has a variety of options for a variety of minerals, including Canada and South America, Australia's reserves have been raised through official channels and have been linked to securing Australian exemptions from the Trump administration's tariffs.

title: Virtual service gives patients easy access to emergency department
text:
When seven-year-old Jaxx Atkinson woke one August night struggling to breathe, his mother Brooke knew he needed help fast.

She called triple-0 and paramedics arrived and quickly stabilised her son.

But for a moment, it was every parent's worst nightmare.

"He was really freaking himself out because he couldn't get a breath in," Ms Atkinson said.

The paramedics determined Jaxx did not need to go to hospital, but should see a doctor.



That meant a 20-minute drive from the family's Newborough home to the local hospital in Traralgon, Gippsland.

With another young child asleep in the next room, a long emergency department wait was not appealing.

So when the Ambulance Victoria paramedic showed Ms Atkinson the Victorian Virtual Emergency Department service she could access from home, it was a relief.

"I didn't think [Jaxx] would go in an ambulance by himself, and I've got [other son] Zavier here too," she said.

"We opted for the virtual ED … it was so much easier than sitting in a waiting room."

Online assistance

The Virtual Emergency Department is an online service run by the state government and Ambulance Victoria in conjunction with Melbourne's Northern Health.

It connects patients in remote areas with doctors, and is designed to triage patients with non-life threatening conditions.

The free service is available at all hours, and can be used by paramedics and the public.

Brooke, Jaxx and Zavier Atkinson reunite with paramedic Jamik Chauchan. (ABC Gippsland: Madeleine Stuchbery)

Jamik Chauchan was one of the paramedics who treated Jaxx.

He showed Ms Atkinson the virtual emergency department before being called to another job.

Amanda Burnside was the doctor who treated Jaxx remotely.

She said the virtual emergency resource worked as a lifeline for patients late at night or early in the morning, especially for parents with other children at home.

"I know in the Gippsland region, access to GPs is quite tricky, there are often long wait times," Dr Burnside said.

"We're kind of covering that gap and helping out those local resources to take the pressure off a little bit."

Ambulance Victoria director regional and clinical operations for Gippsland, Ross Salathiel, said the virtual ED helped provide timely care to patients.

"By using [the service], it helps keep our ambulances ready and available for the sickest patients, particularly those with life-threatening conditions," Mr Salathiel said.

The tyranny of distance

National Rural Health Alliance chief executive Susi Tegen said about 30 per cent of Australians lived in rural, remote and regional areas and experienced inequity in health funding.

"For communities and areas like Bairnsdale [three hours east of Melbourne], the underspend on health, medical, disability and aging care access is up to $4,000 per person per annum less," she said.

Susi Tegen says digital technology can help bridge rural healthcare gaps, but greater investment in the regions is needed. (Supplied: National Rural Health Alliance)

Data from 2023-24 shows people living regionally are 36.3 per cent more likely to face long wait times to access a GP appointment, while 46 per cent of patients nationwide waited more than 24 hours for urgent medical care.

Ms Tegen said state and federal funding did not account for the tyranny of distance in rural healthcare

She said while digital technology "has its place" in diagnosis and treatment, it was not a complete solution.

"Digital healthcare solutions are a welcome efficiency and access tool, indeed enabler," Ms Tegen said.

"However, [they are] not the only and best solution for the development and sustainability of our health and medical workforce, nor will it ensure equitable quality healthcare access for our rural populations."

Paramedic Jamik Chauchan is reunited with patient, Jaxx Atkinson. (ABC Gippsland: Madeleine Stuchbery)

Dr Burnside said there was "room to grow" when it came to patient uptake of virtual clinics.

"We're more than happy to see more people," she said.

"We're still growing by the day, and I think it was a pretty tough flu season this winter and we saw lots of people with influenza coming through.

"We're able to help to, assess them, and provide some treatment and keep them at home and hopefully out of the emergency department."

title: Teen's playground fall costs department $225K fine for failed inspections
text:
South Australia's Education Department has been fined more than $200,000 after a student suffered serious facial injuries when a "severely worn" bolt broke on a swing in a school playground, throwing him to the ground.

A ruling handed down by SA's Employment Tribunal found the swing, at a Port Augusta Special School, had not been "comprehensively" inspected in the eight years prior to the August 2021 incident.

The tribunal's deputy president Stephen Lieschke said 95 per cent of the bolt — one of two which supported the swings chains — had gradually "worn away without anyone ever inspecting it".

"The worn bolt was observable on a visual inspection of the swing's moving parts," he said.

He said Australian standards required quarterly inspections, but "the defendant did not have a system for ensuring" all of its playgrounds in South Australia were included in its centrally controlled inspection and maintenance programs.

"None of the school's playground equipment was ever given a comprehensive annual inspection in the eight years prior to the offence," Mr Lieschke said.

"Nor did any of the quarterly inspections include the load bearing moving parts of the swings."

The bolt on the swing gradually wore away in the years before the student was injured. (Supplied: SafeWork SA)

Instead, he said after the playground was installed in 2012 "daily and quarterly visual inspections were recorded on only five occasions between April 2018 and January 2021".

"There is no evidence the critical load bearing moving parts of the swing were ever inspected on these occasions."

He said testing later revealed there was no manufacturing defect in the worn bolt.

The ruling notes the teenager was "thrown" from the swing when the bolt failed and landed on his head, suffering injuries to his face, forehead eyes and nose.

The 16-year-old was initially treated at the Port Augusta Hospital before being flown to the Royal Adelaide Hospital for surgery.

Mr Lieschke said the boy's father provided a victim impact statement to the tribunal and described his son's injuries as "horrific", with his scars "a constant reminder of the incident".

He said a department representative told the tribunal the playground was immediately fenced off and later decommissioned, before a new one costing about $290,000 was installed.

"The seriousness is aggravated by the defendant placing a particularly vulnerable group of disabled children at risk of serious injury over a long period," the deputy president said.

The tribunal found the Department for Education did not have a system for ensuring all of its playgrounds were inspected as required. (Supplied: SA Government website)

According to the ruling, at the time of the incident "only 360" of the department's playgrounds "were then being inspected as required".

Mr Lieschke said the responsibility for playground equipment inspections was delegated to school principals "without conveying this expectation" or ensuring they occurred.

"The defendant had no system of reviewing, checking or auditing to ensure that all playgrounds were included in its centrally controlled inspection and maintenance program," he said.

" The department's existing safety policy for ensuring the inspection and maintenance of potentially dangerous playground equipment was little more than aspirational. "

He said the department's "considered refusal" to pay the student compensation was "a poor response to its criminal conduct".

He noted an agreement for compensation was later reached, but said the department had "demonstrated very little regard for its victim's welfare, and thereby, a lack of contrition".

The department, who had pleaded guilty to breaching its safety, was convicted and fined $225,000.

title: Titmus admits she lost the 'fire in the belly' before shock retirement
text:
Four-time Olympic gold medallist Ariarne Titmus has revealed she realised she "did not have the fire in the belly in anymore" before deciding to retire from swimming.

Titmus fought back tears as she spoke at Brisbane's New Farm Park on Friday morning, 24 hours after making what she described as "probably the toughest decision of my life".

Following her triumphant Olympic campaign in Paris last year, Titmus took some time away from the pool and said she did not want to "half-arse" a return to competitive swimming.

Live Moment Ariarne Titmus speaks publicly for the first time since announcing her retirement from professional swimming at 25. Au revoir, Arnie! And just like that we're done! Best of luck to Ariarne Titmus on her next chapter. After hearing her speak, there is no question in my mind that she's made the right call. Good on her. Thank you all for following along! Some tears to end the press conference Titmus is asked about whether it is "lovely" to be entering the next chapter of her life, and starts saying she is "very happy" in her personal live and begins to fight back tears. Surprised by interest in retirement news Titmus is so incredibly humble. She says she was taken aback by the reaction and interest in her retirement. "I couldn't believe how quickly it became news and I don't know, [I was] so overwhelmed with how many messages I have had," she says. Show more

Titmus said she was not "nervous or scared" to tell her coach Dean Boxall about her plans to retire.

"I was half expecting him [Boxall] to try and twist my leg to bring me back, and that probably would have been selfish for his part because obviously he did not want me to stop, our partnership has been so fun but he was the opposite," she said.

"He was so happy for me and proud of me and could see that I had so much to look forward to in my life and was happy to support me."

Titmus described her retirement as "a big weight off my shoulders" and remained defiant about her decision, saying people "should not question whether I made the right decision or not".

Titmus said long-time American rival Katie Ledecky (left) was one of the first people to congratulate her on her retirement. (Getty Images: Quinn Rooney)

"At the end of the day, it is a decision about my life and I have to do what makes me happy," she said.

"People can have their own thoughts on those things but I know I am content with this.

" I don't think you realise how difficult it is until you remove yourself from the environment and it is hard going into Olympic Games as favourite and rising to the challenge and defending your title. "

She described US rival Katie Ledecky as her "Goliath", revealing the American had been one of the first people to congratulate her on her career.

"I feel really proud of that relationship we have because it goes to show you can leave everything in the pool and still be a good person when you are not racing, so I hope I have left that legacy as well," she said.

Titmus said she plans to pursue a career in broadcasting in swimming and other sports, embracing the chance to "do things that I have never done before". She hopes to be a part of the broadcast at the Los Angeles Olympics in 2028.

title: King Charles marks land rights milestone in first visit to London's Australia House
text:
King Charles has marked a major Aboriginal land rights milestone alongside Uluru-Kata Tjuta's traditional owners.

He attended a commemoration for the 40th anniversary of the Uluru handback in his first visit to London's Australia House since he became king.

On October 26, 1985, the Commonwealth government handed the title deeds for Uluru-Kata Tjuta back to its traditional owners, known as Anangu.

Traditional owners say they want to keep their culture alive and strong for future generations. (Reuters: Jack Taylor)

"It sort of brings us into tears and sadness, but happiness as well," Sammy Wilson said via interpreter and fellow traditional owner Harry Wilson.

They were among a group of nine Anangu who swapped the red dirt of the outback for the marble floors of Australia House for the commemoration.

Nine Anangu commemorated the anniversary alongside the king. (Reuters: Jack Taylor)

Australia's High Commissioner to the UK, Stephen Smith, said the monarch's attendance was a symbol of profound respect for Anangu.

"When the king engages in anniversary events, normally the palace looks at 50 or 100 year anniversaries," Mr Smith said.

" So the fact that we're doing this on the 40th anniversary tells you this was something special. "

Stephen Smith said the monarch's attendance was a symbol of profound respect for Anangu. (Reuters: Jack Taylor)

The long road to the handback

The first step towards the handback was taken in 1976, when the Australian government passed the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

For the first time Indigenous Australians had a legal pathway to claim land where traditional ownership could be proven.

The first step towards the handback was taken in 1976. (Reuters: Stefica Bikes)

Nine years later the Hawke government handed back the title deeds for the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park.

Hundreds gathered to watch the ceremony in front of Uluru.

"For all Aboriginal people right around Australia, a very important day," the event's emcee told the cheering crowd.

But not everyone was so enthusiastic.

King Charles met with Uluru-Kata Tjuta's traditional owners, who hope there might be another royal visit to Australia on the cards. (Supplied: Mark Hilton)

The NT's then-leader Ian Tuxworth campaigned against the handback and unsuccessfully demanded that the Commonwealth hand Uluru to the Territory government.

Then-federal opposition leader John Howard suggested there could be a need to buy it back in the future.

Neither proposal was successful.

The dissenters have long fallen silent and traditional ownership has flourished.

King Charles joined guests to watch a traditional performance at the Australian High Commission in London. (Reuters: Jack Taylor)

"Our vision for the national park is that it is a place where Tjukurpa – Aṉangu law and culture – can be kept strong for future generations," said Tapaya Edwards, chair of the Uluṟu-Kata Tjuṯa National Park's board of management.

"There is still much work to be done and, over the next 40 years, we look forward to seeing our young people carry this flame forward as they learn Aṉangu traditional knowledge and Western knowledge to care for country and keep Tjukurpa strong."

Rumours of a royal return

The traditional owners, who are preparing to make the long trip back to Australia, say they hope there will be a royal return to Uluru.

King Charles visited the National Park in 1983, before the handover, followed by Prince William and Princess Catherine in 2014.

Nine Anangu met with King Charles at Australia House. (Supplied: Mark Hilton)

The Anangu delegation in London remembered the latter trip fondly.

"Sammy actually took Kate and William on a tour in the previous years when they visited last time at Uluru," Mr Wilson said.

"Sammy spoke to him [Prince William] and said, 'Would you like to come back in the future?' And he said, 'I will come back.' And now he's coming back, I reckon."

Princess Catherine and Prince William visited Uluru in 2014. (Reuters: Phil Noble)

The comments come amid growing rumours of a royal tour of Australia.

"That would be a matter for the palace and a matter for the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet," Mr Smith said with a smile.

In the meantime, the Anangu will return home for the anniversary, where the prime minister will join them for celebrations on country.

title: Outback communities reflect on actions taken one year on from power outages
text:
A year ago a freak weather event flattened seven power transmission towers and plunged thousands of homes and businesses throughout far west New South Wales into darkness for several weeks.

Abigail Hughes's cafe was one of more than 10,000 homes and businesses in Broken Hill and outlying towns hit hard by the outage.

"We lost over $30,000 as a whole, so that was pretty full on," Ms Hughes said.

"I would say we've tried to recoup that, but that's only been through a lot of hard work and sacrifice."

Local cafe owner Abigail Hughes says it's been a long road to recovery. (ABC Broken Hill: Oliver Brown)

"We were affected pretty heavily, we lost quite a few days' trade, as did everybody."

Fellow business owner David Trinder had similar losses of about $20,000 through lost trade, expired stock and the resulting clean-up.

He said that while he attempted to claim some of this money back through insurance, the administrative task was too exhausting to finalise.

"Coming off the back of previous insurance claims with all the hailstorms in 2016, all the premiums had gone up," Mr Trinder said.

Loading...

"So when we all came in for this claim, trying to legitimise everything was like pulling teeth [because] they wanted every detail, pictures, to quantify profit and losses.

"You can imagine trying to get that information to them and run your business, rather than coming to some negotiated settlement of reasonableness. It wasn't working.

"So we've actually moved on, and we didn't get any claim from [the blackouts]."

The blackouts also forced the city's largest employer, the mines, to stand down hundreds of its workers until the main supply was restored.

David and Maryanne Trinder felt the process of reclaiming their losses was exhausting. (ABC Broken Hill: Youssef Saudie)

Flawed backup system

Within days of the outage, the NSW government declared it a natural disaster.

The situation was worsened by one of the city's two diesel-powered emergency back-up generators being offline for maintenance, leaving the other unable to cope with demand.

While smaller generators were transported to affected communities over time, it meant some areas experienced further rolling blackouts, some of them lasting days.

Broken Hill resident Rita Bruggy, 77, said this, coupled with poor community consultation, was a failure on the part of privately-owned network operator Transgrid.

"Being the organisation that they are, I feel that Transgrid could have done more, and they should do more with the upkeep of their generators," she said.

Rita Bruggy and her husband Michael [left] believe Transgrid has a lot to answer for. (ABC Broken Hill: Oliver Brown)

"It might cost you a dollar [but] we're paying for it, and we want a service."

Transgrid, aided by Essential Energy, installed temporary transmission towers to restore the main supply in the weeks following, before erecting permanent replacements earlier this year.

Lessons learned?

Transgrid general manager of operations and maintenance Sam Pickering said the organisation was in a much better position than it was 12 months ago.

"That gas turbine that was unavailable is now fully refurbished and available after extensive works," he said.

"We've also brought in portable generation to further provide that back-up supply and strengthen our network resilience."

Transgird’s general manager of operations and maintenance Sam Pickering. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

A NSW government spokesperson said it had rolled out more than $2.5 million in financial and in-kind support through individual and small business grants, food and fuel vouchers and food hampers.

The NSW Reconstruction Authority also established a Recovery Assistance Point in Broken Hill and conducted outreach to surrounding communities also affected, including Wilcannia, Menindee and White Cliffs.

Investigations ongoing

While the days and weeks following the blackouts were dedicated to retaining a consistent power supply and community recovery, the months to come were just as busy.

The NSW Parliament, the NSW Independent Pricing and Regulatory Tribunal (IPART) and the Australian Energy Regulator (AER) each launched independent inquiries with different focuses.

Only one, headed up by the Legislative Assembly Committee on Environment and Planning, has publicly handed down its findings based on a range of online and in person submissions.

IPART's Jonathon Coppel says its inquiry into the outage is progressing well. (Supplied: IPART)

One of the key recommendations was that electricity companies that breached their licences should be forced to compensate affected customers.

IPART is yet to determine if the actions of Transgrid warranted a breach.

Member Jonathon Coppel said their investigation had been "complex and quite technical", but at the same time it was "well-progressed".

Meanwhile, a spokesperson for the AER said its own investigation into whether Transgrid breached the National Electricity Rules would be concluded in the coming months.

Communities need more than nice words

According to the Bureau of Meteorology (BOM), the outage was caused by two supercell thunderstorms, and possibly a tornado.

But without direct evidence from radar or damage reports, it was hard to know for sure, as well as the likelihood of a similar damaging weather event happening again in the future.

Broken Hill Mayor Tom Kennedy said he was comfortable things were moving in the right direction to ensure a similar aftermath was avoided, but there was a lot to do.

"Some of the findings and some of the things that will come out of the inquiries will easily transfer to everywhere in the country and make it a lot better for the whole of NSW and the country," he said.

title: Union criticises fine for mining company over worker's death
text:
A Queensland mining union says an $80,000 fine handed to an international mining company this week is not enough of a deterrent for companies to avoid putting workers in unsafe situations.

International mining giant Coronado Global Resources, through its subsidiary Coronado Curragh, was fined $80,000, plus court costs of $28,572.78, in Rockhampton Magistrates Court on Wednesday over the death of a worker in November 2021.

No conviction was recorded.

The fine was for breaching health and safety obligations under the Coal Mining and Safety Act 1999 after experienced worker Clark Peadon, 54, died on site at the Curragh North open-cut mine, north of Blackwater.

The company was charged three years after the incident, with the maximum penalty under the Act $689,250.

Mitch Hughes described the fine as appalling for the loss of someone's life. (ABC Tropical North: Abbey Halter)

Mining and Energy Union Queensland district president Mitch Hughes said while he understood the courts were limited by the penalties they could issue, the fine was not enough.

"To sit here and see that they've only been given an $80,000 fine for someone's life is pretty inadequate in our view," he said.

According to Queensland government data, in the past five years seven Queensland coal mine workers have died.

"If the government and the minister and the regulator want to do something about deterring companies from putting workers in unsafe situations, then that's probably a good place to start, is looking at increasing the penalties that are available," Mr Hughes said.

New safety technology introduced

Curragh mine in central Queensland. (ABC News: Jemima Burt)

At the time of the accident, Mr Peadon was conducting cable relocation work when he was crushed by a dragline shoe.

Court documents show the company has spent $5 million over the past three years on developing an industry-first engineering system to prevent precisely the type of incident from occurring again.

The Proximity Awareness System (PAS) uses three different sensing technologies — optical, light detection and ranging and radar — to create three bands of detection and vision around the dragline to automatically stop it from operating if it senses a person's presence in that area.

The documents show this system has been installed on three of the four draglines at the mine site, with the fourth to be installed next year.

Peer mining companies and RSHQ have also visited the mine to view the PAS in operation.

As part of its defence, the company said it had also reviewed and added new safety procedures following the accident.

More improvements needed

More than 2,000 workers are employed at the Curragh mine in the Bowen Basin.

Coronado Curragh took ownership of the Curragh North mine seven years ago and employs 400 workers and 2,000 contractors.

Eighteen months prior to Mr Peadon's death, another worker also died at the Curragh mine site.

Donald Rabbit, 33, died in January 2020 when he was trapped by a heavy falling tyre and rim.

Coronado Curragh and mining contractor Thiess were initially charged with breaching the Coal Mining Safety and Health Act 1999, but all charges were later dropped.

Mr Hughes said while there had been some safety improvements for miners since Mr Peadon's death, more needed to be done.

"We have sadly still seen fatalities occur," he said.

"The work to improve health and safety for all coal mine work has never stopped.

"We've obviously got to look at these investigations and determine some outcomes to prevent them happening again."

title: Team orders are out of the window, Oscar can now play by 'Piastri rules'
text:
If Formula 1 — like many of the world's pre-eminent dictionaries — had a word or phrase of the year, 2025's winner would be "Papaya rules".

It is the mythical code that McLaren has adhered to like a sacred text for the past two seasons, as the former backmarker rose to the top of F1.

Papaya rules has ensured drivers Oscar Piastri and Lando Norris achieved maximum points for the team every weekend, en route to back-to-back F1 constructors' championships.

Papaya rules is built on three cornerstones:

Do what is best for the team

Do not crash into each other

Ensure both drivers have a fair playing field

Until now, papaya rules has worked on the same principle that governs antiques: it only has value if others place value on it.

'That's not fair': Piastri's F1 lead cut after Norris makes lap one contact Oscar Piastri has been left furious at his teammate, and his team, after his two drivers' championship rivals gained ground on him in the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix.

Piastri and Norris, until now, have placed value on papaya rules.

It is why Norris let Piastri overtake him for the lead in Hungary 2024, when McLaren's pit strategy allowed the Brit to emerge in front after being behind the Australian by several seconds.

It is why Piastri allowed Norris to retake second place in Monza this year, after a slow pit stop for the Brit had allowed the Australian to overtake him late in the race.

But after the Singapore Grand Prix, Piastri may have lessened the value he places on papaya rules.

The Australian was left ropeable in the cockpit after his teammate overshot the third corner of the grand prix, clipped the back of Max Verstappen in front, then clattered into the side of Piastri.

The hit to the side of Piastri's McLaren could have sent the Australian into the barrier, but it certainly helped Norris move into third place.

Piastri bemoaned over team radio that they should tell Norris to give the place back.

"That's not fair, I'm sorry. That's not fair," Piastri said over his radio.

"If he has to avoid another car by crashing into his teammate, then that's a pretty s*** job at avoiding."

In any other team, Norris's move on Piastri would be fair game. It was an aggressive move for position by a driver who wants to win the world championship.

Loading Instagram content

Norris's move, while not the cleanest, is no different from many that the likes of Verstappen, Ayrton Senna and Michael Schumacher have been praised for.

But in the world of papaya rules, Norris breached two of its cornerstones.

Norris made contact with a teammate, and, in Piastri's mind, the Australian was unfairly penalised.

For Piastri, this was the time for papaya rules to ensure he was not disadvantaged — but it never came.

The Australian was furious in the car, cut a frustrated figure in the media pen, and watched his lead in the drivers' championship narrow to 22 points.

This is not the first time in 2025 that Piastri's call for papaya rules fell on deaf ears.

He was denied victory in the British Grand Prix due to a penalty that McLaren argued against. Despite believing Piastri's penalty was unjust, they did not tell Norris to give the lead of the race back to the Australian — something Piastri himself requested.

Piastri finished second to Norris in Hungary this year after McLaren — unbeknownst to him at the time — put the Brit on a better pit strategy than the Australian. Then at Imola, another advantageous pit strategy for Norris, who was behind Piastri, allowed the Brit again to finish ahead of him.

Piastri has had his share of fortune this year, but none that necessitated the McLaren team needing to make a decision.

Fuelled by the disappointment of Singapore, the Australian may now be able to free himself from the papaya rules burden and play by "Piastri rules".

Piastri rules are built on one basic principle — excellence on track.

F1 title battle explained Formula 1 returns to the United States, officially marking the final quarter of an epic 2025 championship. Here is what is to come.

Despite finishing behind Norris, and other title rival Verstappen, in the previous three grands prix, Piastri still holds a solid advantage of 22 and 63 points over his rivals.

He has won seven grands prix this season, more than any other driver.

In qualifying, he has been faster than Norris in 10 of the 18 grand prix shootouts. The Australian has been faster than Norris in all three qualifying sessions for sprint races as well.

Sprint weekends have been a strength for Piastri in 2025. He has finished second in all three sprint races this season, and then gone on to win the grand prix the following day.

Of the six weekends left this season, three involve a sprint race, including this weekend's action in Austin, Texas.

Piastri's excellence is not only measured in wins and podiums.

Twice he has been awarded F1's Overtake of the Month.

His overtake in March of Lewis Hamilton on the final lap in Melbourne, after spinning out of second place earlier in the race, showed character and grit.

In April, Piastri showed supreme confidence through the narrow streets of Jeddah to again pass Hamilton, in a section of track not associated with overtaking.

It is these triumphs that have the Australian in a position to win a maiden world championship.

No papaya rules. No team orders. Just raw pace and excellence on track — Piastri rules.

Should Piastri be able to part ways with the disappointment of Singapore and maintain the driving that has earned him a championship lead this late in the season, he will be in the prime position to achieve the ultimate prize.

title: Leaking pipes, fallen ceilings and black mould plague housing development
text:
After spending three years living in a caravan with her two children, Nicheliving customer Kathy Ellis thought her nightmare was finally over in July, only to discover water pouring from the ceiling shortly after she moved into her new home.

One bathroom in the house is now unusable, sections of the house have black mould, and some walls and ceilings have collapsed due to water damage.

Ms Ellis was among the hundreds caught in the Nicheliving building crisis after the company took years longer than promised to complete their homes.

It ended late last year when the state government reached an agreement with Nicheliving directors Ronnie Michel-Elhaj and Paul Bitdorf to surrender their building licence.

In return, customers with incomplete homes would be allowed to access building indemnity insurance payments of $200,000 to complete their homes.

Some of the mould growing in Kathy Ellis's house. (Supplied: Kathy Ellis)

Inspections have since revealed that the appropriate plumbing pipe was not installed in Ms Ellis's house.

"They've actually used communications PVC pipe and none of the joins are glued together," Ms Ellis told Nadia Mitsopoulos on ABC Radio Perth.

A full inspection by the regulator, Building and Energy, has revealed 10 breaches by the plumber Nicheliving appointed to do the work.

The report reveals that some pipes are flowing in the wrong direction, the size of the connections is wrong, pipes are at incorrect angles, and pipe joints are not watertight.

"It's on the severe side of serious. The inspectors that came out spent many hours at my house looking over it, and they said that even they were surprised at how many breaches they found just in one house," she said.

"I currently have no ceilings in the living area of my house. One bathroom, we can't use at all.

"The other bathroom we can use, but we have to have very quick showers.

" Luckily, when the ceilings fell down … all the mould got taken outside in that area. "

Plumber ordered to fix work

Building and Energy have now issued a rectification order to the plumber who did the work.

"He has the option not to do as ordered, but then I'm presuming the plumber's licensing board will have a lot to say about that if he doesn't," Ms Ellis said.

If he does come back and repair the plumbing, Ms Ellis will still have to cover the cost of the damage caused to other parts of the house herself.

She said the indemnity payment would cover some of the estimated $60,000 cost, but she will have to pay out around $20,000 herself.

Black mould is blooming in a cornice at Kathy Ellis's new house. (Supplied: Kathy Ellis)

'A terrible period of life'

Peter Bentley went through a similar experience with Nicheliving and eventually had his house completed by another builder.

"Our second builder went through our Niche build and managed to find all the problems and rectify them before we finished the build, which was great, but very expensive," he said.

"There was multiple, problems, embarrassing building problems, including having to replace the roof.

"The plumbing and brickwork were terrible."

Nicheliving loses legal authority to complete home builds A Perth home builder with scores of unfinished projects on the books is no longer able to legally undertake construction works.

The house was finished three years past the original completion date.

Mr Bentley said his family eventually moved into the finished house for a short period before selling it.

"We were just so disturbed by the entire process. So we've sold it and moved on.

"We're not suffering as a result of any of this, compared to others

"Nonetheless, it was a terrible period of life for us and for a whole lot of other people."

title: Peter V’landys and the turf war splitting Sydney racing on Everest day
text:
Racing NSW and the ATC were at odds ahead of The Everest carnival over the terms of a deal to establish Base Camp, a new $7 million trackside corporate enclosure driven by V’landys, which has been set up in such a rush that building work is expected to continue through Friday night. The sacking of ATC chief executive Matt Galanos then set off a chain of events that led to a sensational public admonishment of the club by Racing NSW chair Saranne Cooke, technically V’landys’ boss, who warned there were “significant doubts about its ability to survive without ongoing bailouts”. Australian Turf Club chairman Tim Hale argues the member-owned organisation is financially secure. Credit: Steven Siewert Two club directors quit, with one going public with claims of dysfunction on the board, leaving only four remaining – Hale, media personality Caroline Searcy, technology executive and horse owner David McGrath, and Annette English, a commercial lawyer with close ties to the breeding industry. Three of them were opposed to the controversial proposed $5 billion sale of Rosehill for housing, which triggered a parliamentary inquiry last year before ultimately being defeated by members in May.

The Racing NSW intervention has brought the sport’s complex, much-debated flow of hundreds of millions of dollars a year in wagering revenue into back into focus. Most of it lands in the coffers of Racing NSW, which straddles the roles of both regulator and commercial juggernaut, distributing money onwards but also accumulating a war chest that includes $150 million in property. V’landys told last year’s Rosehill inquiry an extra $3 billion had been injected into the industry thanks to Racing NSW’s 2012 High Court win that made the bookies pay up and as a result of its negotiations with the state government on betting-related taxes. Last year’s Everest day was attended by a record crowd of 49,117. Credit: Getty “This is all new money. Racing NSW’s initiatives have made the money and now some want the keys to the castle,” he said in a written presentation to inquiry committee members. Hale says these are “industry funds” and much of what is channelled to the club from Racing NSW is earmarked for prizemoney and bonuses paid directly to owners rather than for the club’s operating costs.

V’landys told this masthead the club’s costs had soared and it was not generating enough of its own revenue. “Whatever way you look at it, we’re giving them a lot more money than we’ve ever given them,” he said. With the blowtorch on ATC’s governance, including unspecified alleged code of conduct breaches by directors, eyebrows have also been raised about how Racing NSW has conducted itself. Just this week, the NSW parliament’s privileges committee delivered it a slapdown for its behaviour during the Rosehill inquiry, while this masthead earlier this year reported how Cooke transferred a block of land near Bathurst racecourse to Racing NSW for $1 after buying it in her own name. It also emerged at the inquiry that Racing NSW did not have a human resources department, but a “HR function” carried out by general managers. Cooke said at the time there was nothing inappropriate about the land deal, on which stamp duty was paid by Racing NSW. V’landys maintained the organisation was just defending itself with letters sent to the Rosehill inquiry that included allegations of impropriety against former staff it believed were behind confidential evidence about Racing NSW.

Mark Latham, a perennial thorn in V’landys’ side, has been Racing NSW’s loudest detractor but in the strangest of twists has become an ally of sorts in the ATC affair – if only of the enemy-of-your-enemy-is-your-friend kind. Furious at being banned from the club’s tracks over a run-in with club executive Steve McMahon and thrown out of Randwick a fortnight ago, the Independent MP has branded Hale as “Jellyfish Tim”, saying he hopes the board is sacked. As for V’landys himself, there have been fresh questions from industry critics about dual roles as racing’s boss and a hands-on chairman of the Australian Rugby League Commission, specifically about how much attention he can devote to his full-time job when he is in charge of two major sports. After more than two decades atop racing, his future has been the subject of much speculation. The latest rumour spreading like wildfire is that he will run the Brisbane Olympic Games in 2032. V’landys doesn’t know how it got started – “no one has contacted me” – and there is nothing to indicate there is any basis to it.

title: Meet the next generation of coaches hoping to launch into the NRL
text:
When it was determined the Brisbane Broncos needed someone to inject a tough, physical edge, one of their former enforcers was identified as the perfect candidate.

Ben Te’o made a triumphant return to Red Hill after spearheading the Redcliffe Dolphins to the Queensland Cup final in 2024, tasked with turning the underperforming NRL outfit into a defensive juggernaut.

Ben Te’o made an immediate impression at the Brisbane Broncos. Credit: Getty
